item.title: This Week in Science
item.description: There Goes the Neighborhood | Sourcing Martian Meteorites | Productive Dustiness | Cytologically Informative Fossils | All the Smells of the World | Predation Favors Parasitism | Giving Electrocatalysts an Edge | Coordinated Hair Growth | HIV Virulence | Oscillate to Synchronize | Ultrafast Manipulation | The Cuprate Pseudogap | Life and Cell Death | Transcripts Visualized in Situ | Serial Mutation | Translocation in Injury | Real Network Control

item.title: [Editorial] Exxon Valdez: 25 Years Later
item.dc:creator: Marcia McNutt
item.description: After I was Called upon in 2010, as Director of the U.S. Geological Survey, to Help with well control and flow estimation for the Deepwater Horizon (DWH) oil spill, I reviewed what had been learned from the Exxon Valdez (EV) oil spill. Although EV and DWH differed in their spill characteristics and impacts, I suspected that insight gained in the decades since EV could help guide how to best invest research funds targeted for DWH recovery and future oil spill prevention Author: Marcia McNutt

item.title: Editors' Choice
item.dc:creator: Sacha Vignieri
item.description: Skunky or Social | Growing Back Hearing? | Root Down | Defect Control
item.dc:subject: Evolution

item.title: [News of the Week] This Week's Section
item.description: Follow the links below for a roundup of the week's top stories in science, or download a PDF of the entire section. Around the WorldFindingsRandom SamplesNewsmakers

item.title: [News of the Week] Around the World
item.description: In science news around the world, the European Parliament approves tighter data privacy rules, a report from U.K. scientists criticizes the European Union's approval process for genetically modified crops, and more.

item.title: [News of the Week] Random Sample
item.description: When an intern at the Hunterian Museum of the University of Glasgow in Scotland discovered a slide of the Blarney Stone in the museum collection, geologists there put its mythical origins to the test.

item.title: [News of the Week] Newsmakers
item.description: The U.S. Senate has confirmed astrophysicist France Córdova, formerly chair of the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution, as the new director of the National Science Foundation.

item.title: Findings
item.description: 'Little Foot' Fossil Could Be a Human Ancestor

item.title: [News & Analysis] First Wrinkles in Spacetime Confirm Cosmic Inflation
item.dc:creator: Adrian Cho
item.description: Signs of gravitational waves shaking the newborn universe bolster the mind-boggling theory of cosmic inflation and electrify scientists the world over. Authors: Adrian Cho, Yudhijit Bhattacharjee
item.dc:subject: Cosmology

item.title: [News & Analysis] Hints of Detente Between NSF and Republicans
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Mervis
item.description: Congressional Republicans and the National Science Foundation appear to be creeping toward common ground in their yearlong fight over how the agency manages its $7 billion research portfolio. Author: Jeffrey Mervis
item.dc:subject: U.S. Science Policy

item.title: [News & Analysis] Dueling Visions for Agency
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Mervis
item.description: The Democratic alternative to the Republican bill would encourage the National Science Foundation to support more of the same high-quality research it now funds. Author: Jeffrey Mervis

item.title: [News & Analysis] Irreproducibility Dogs New Reprogramming Method
item.dc:creator: Dennis Normile
item.description: As scientists around the world attempt to reproduce a new way to make stem cells—so far without success—Science has learned that several co-authors on the feted papers have not yet made the cells either. Authors: Dennis Normile, Gretchen Vogel
item.dc:subject: Stem Cells

item.title: [News & Analysis] U.S. and Mexico Unleash a Flood Into Colorado Delta
item.dc:creator: Erik Stokstad
item.description: Hoping for a boost to native vegetation, scientists will study the effects of an experimental flood of the Colorado River delta on trees, soil salinity, and ground water. Author: Erik Stokstad
item.dc:subject: Restoration Ecology

item.title: [News Focus] A War Within a War
item.dc:creator: Leslie Roberts
item.description: Fighting a major polio outbreak in the midst of Syria's bitter civil war is a test of commitment—and diplomacy. Author: Leslie Roberts

item.title: [News Focus] The Vigilante
item.dc:creator: Yudhijit Bhattacharjee
item.description: When the ENCODE Project declared that there is no such thing as junk DNA, Dan Graur counterattacked. But does he go too far? Author: Yudhijit Bhattacharjee

item.title: [Letter] When Science-Based Management Isn't
item.dc:creator: Kyle A. Artelle
item.description: Authors: Kyle A. Artelle, John D. Reynolds, Paul C. Paquet, Chris T. Darimont

item.title: [Letter] U.S. Policy Impedes Innovators
item.dc:creator: Arolyn Conwill
item.description: Authors: Arolyn Conwill, Yuqing Cui, Daniel Day

item.title: [Letter] Supporting the Scientific Diaspora
item.dc:creator: Shermin de Silva
item.description: Author: Shermin de Silva

item.title: [Correction] Corrections and Clarifications
[Book Review] To Connect More Equitably
item.dc:creator: Emily Brennan
item.description: Research on the ways people learn and share information about health and science, Southwell argues, suggest that systematic reliance on social networks will increase inequity. Author: Emily Brennan
item.dc:subject: Social Sciences

item.title: [Book Review] Wonders from Cambridge Collections
item.dc:creator: Deborah Dixon
item.description: Juxtaposing objects from eight Cambridge University museums, the exhibition illustrates links among art, science, and exploration. Author: Deborah Dixon
item.dc:subject: Exhibition

item.title: [Books et al.] Books Received
item.description: A listing of books received at Science during the week ending 14 March 2014.

item.title: [Policy Forum] Carbon Market Lessons and Global Policy Outlook
item.dc:creator: Richard G. Newell
item.description: Ongoing work on linking markets and mixing policies builds on successes and failures in pricing and trading carbon. Authors: Richard G. Newell, William A. Pizer, Daniel Raimi
item.dc:subject: Environmental Economics

item.title: [Perspective] Testing the Limits of Accretion
item.dc:creator: Andrew King
item.description: Observations reveal a greater influence of rapidly accreting black holes on their host galaxy than expected. [Also see Report by Soria et al.] Author: Andrew King
item.dc:subject: Astronomy

item.title: [Perspective] Nanoframe Catalysts
item.dc:creator: Julia R. Greer
item.description: Nanoframe electrocatalysts containing only small amounts of precious metal show very high activities. [Also see Report by Chen et al.] Author: Julia R. Greer
item.dc:subject: Chemistry

item.title: [Perspective] Unlocking Ancient Protein Palimpsests
item.dc:creator: Enrico Cappellini
item.description: High-resolution, high-throughput mass spectrometry studies of ancient protein samples provide insights into protein function in the distant past. Authors: Enrico Cappellini, Matthew J. Collins, M. Thomas P. Gilbert
item.dc:subject: Biochemistry

item.title: [Perspective] RIPK3 Takes Another Deadly Turn
item.dc:creator: Jianke Zhang
item.description: Blocking an enzyme involved in necroptosis may prove toxic by promoting another form of cell death. [Also see Report by Newton et al.] Authors: Jianke Zhang, Francis Ka-Ming Chan
item.dc:subject: Cell Biology

item.title: [Perspective] Epstein-Barr Virus Turns 50
item.dc:creator: Paul M. Lieberman
item.description: Fifty years after the discovery of Epstein-Barr virus and its association with cancer, a vaccine or therapy for the virus remains elusive. Author: Paul M. Lieberman
item.dc:subject: Virology

item.title: [Perspective] Flow of Control in Networks
item.dc:creator: Jukka-Pekka “JP” Onnela
item.description: A simple framework allows the classification of complex networks based on the flow of control. [Also see Report by Ruths and Ruths] Author: Jukka-Pekka “JP” Onnela
item.dc:subject: Physics

item.title: [Perspective] Counting the Ways to Decode Dynamic Signals
item.dc:creator: Roy Wollman
item.description: The social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum decodes an oscillatory signal to measure time. [Also see Research Article by Cai et al.] Author: Roy Wollman
item.dc:subject: Development

item.title: [Review] Virulence and Pathogenesis of HIV-1 Infection: An Evolutionary Perspective
item.dc:creator: Christophe Fraser
item.description: Why some individuals develop AIDS rapidly whereas others remain healthy without treatment for many years remains a central question of HIV research. An evolutionary perspective reveals an apparent conflict between two levels of selection on the virus. On the one hand, there is rapid evolution of the virus in the host, and on the other, new observations indicate the existence of virus factors that affect the virulence of infection whose influence persists over years in infected individuals and across transmission events. Here, we review recent evidence that shows that viral genetic factors play a larger role in modulating disease severity than anticipated. We propose conceptual models that reconcile adaptive evolution at both levels of selection. Evolutionary analysis provides new insight into HIV pathogenesis. Authors: Christophe Fraser, Katrina Lythgoe, Gabriel E. Leventhal, George Shirreff, T. Déirdre Hollingsworth, Samuel Alizon, Sebastian Bonhoeffer

item.title: [Research Article] Nucleocytoplasmic Shuttling of a GATA Transcription Factor Functions as a Development Timer
item.dc:creator: Huaqing Cai
item.description: The link between chemoattractant gradients, developmental signals, and gene expression in social amoebae is elucidated. [Also see Perspective by Wollman] Authors: Huaqing Cai, Mariko Katoh-Kurasawa, Tetsuya Muramoto, Balaji Santhanam, Yu Long, Lei Li, Masahiro Ueda, Pablo A. Iglesias, Gad Shaulsky, Peter N. Devreotes

item.title: [Report] Super-Eddington Mechanical Power of an Accreting Black Hole in M83
item.dc:creator: R. Soria
item.description: A stellar-mass black hole shocks its surroundings with kinetic energy in excess of its predicted radiative output. [Also see Perspective by King] Authors: R. Soria, K. S. Long, W. P. Blair, L. Godfrey, K. D. Kuntz, E. Lenc, C. Stockdale, P. F. Winkler

item.title: [Report] Large-Amplitude Spin Dynamics Driven by a THz Pulse in Resonance with an Electromagnon
item.dc:creator: T. Kubacka
item.description: The electric field of an electromagnetic pulse exerts ultrafast control on the spin dynamics of the multiferroic TbMnO3. Authors: T. Kubacka, J. A. Johnson, M. C. Hoffmann, C. Vicario, S. de Jong, P. Beaud, S. Grübel, S.-W. Huang, L. Huber, L. Patthey, Y.-D. Chuang, J. J. Turner, G. L. Dakovski, W.-S. Lee, M. P. Minitti, W. Schlotter, R. G. Moore, C. P. Hauri, S. M. Koohpayeh, V. Scagnoli, G. Ingold, S. L. Johnson, U. Staub

item.title: [Report] Angular Fluctuations of a Multicomponent Order Describe the Pseudogap of YBa2Cu3O6+x
item.dc:creator: Lauren E. Hayward
item.description: A model reproduces the temperature dependence of charge-order fluctuations in a cuprate superconductor. Authors: Lauren E. Hayward, David G. Hawthorn, Roger G. Melko, Subir Sachdev

item.title: [Report] Highly Crystalline Multimetallic Nanoframes with Three-Dimensional Electrocatalytic Surfaces
item.dc:creator: Chen Chen
item.description: Highly active electrocatalysts are created by eroding away all but the edges of platinum-nickel nanocrystals. [Also see Perspective by Greer] Authors: Chen Chen, Yijin Kang, Ziyang Huo, Zhongwei Zhu, Wenyu Huang, Huolin L. Xin, Joshua D. Snyder, Dongguo Li, Jeffrey A. Herron, Manos Mavrikakis, Miaofang Chi, Karren L. More, Yadong Li, Nenad M. Markovic, Gabor A. Somorjai, Peidong Yang, Vojislav R. Stamenkovic

item.title: [Report] The Source Crater of Martian Shergottite Meteorites
item.dc:creator: Stephanie C. Werner
item.description: Martian meteorites originated from the 3- to 5-million-year-old Mojave impact crater. Authors: Stephanie C. Werner, Anouck Ody, François Poulet

item.title: [Report] Iron Fertilization of the Subantarctic Ocean During the Last Ice Age
item.dc:creator: Alfredo Martínez-García
item.description: Nitrogen isotopes in foraminifera show the role of iron fertilization on atmospheric carbon dioxide during the last ice age. Authors: Alfredo Martínez-García, Daniel M. Sigman, Haojia Ren, Robert F. Anderson, Marietta Straub, David A. Hodell, Samuel L. Jaccard, Timothy I. Eglinton, Gerald H. Haug

item.title: [Report] From Parasitism to Mutualism: Unexpected Interactions Between a Cuckoo and Its Host
item.dc:creator: Daniela Canestrari
item.description: The carrion crow Corvus corone corone can benefit from parasitism by the great spotted cuckoo Clamator glandarius. Authors: Daniela Canestrari, Diana Bolopo, Ted C. J. Turlings, Gregory Röder, José M. Marcos, Vittorio Baglione

item.title: [Report] β-Catenin Activation Regulates Tissue Growth Non–Cell Autonomously in the Hair Stem Cell Niche
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth R. Deschene
item.description: Signals generated by mouse hair follicle stem cells generate new hair growth. Authors: Elizabeth R. Deschene, Peggy Myung, Panteleimon Rompolas, Giovanni Zito, Thomas Yang Sun, Makoto M. Taketo, Ichiko Saotome, Valentina Greco

item.title: [Report] Activity of Protein Kinase RIPK3 Determines Whether Cells Die by Necroptosis or Apoptosis
item.dc:creator: Kim Newton
item.description: A particular protein kinase functions at a critical control point that determines whether—and how—cells die. [Also see Perspective by Zhang and Chan] Authors: Kim Newton, Debra L. Dugger, Katherine E. Wickliffe, Neeraj Kapoor, M. Cristina de Almagro, Domagoj Vucic, Laszlo Komuves, Ronald E. Ferrando, Dorothy M. French, Joshua Webster, Merone Roose-Girma, Søren Warming, Vishva M. Dixit

item.title: [Report] Highly Multiplexed Subcellular RNA Sequencing in Situ
item.dc:creator: Je Hyuk Lee
item.description: Reads of cellular RNA transcripts demonstrate spatial expression differences during simulated wound healing. Authors: Je Hyuk Lee, Evan R. Daugharthy, Jonathan Scheiman, Reza Kalhor, Joyce L. Yang, Thomas C. Ferrante, Richard Terry, Sauveur S. F. Jeanty, Chao Li, Ryoji Amamoto, Derek T. Peters, Brian M. Turczyk, Adam H. Marblestone, Samuel A. Inverso, Amy Bernard, Prashant Mali, Xavier Rios, John Aach, George M. Church

item.title: [Report] Structure of the Mitochondrial Translocator Protein in Complex with a Diagnostic Ligand
item.dc:creator: Łukasz Jaremko
item.description: A ligand stabilizes a mammalian mitochondrial cholesterol transporter, allowing high-resolution structural analysis. Authors: Łukasz Jaremko, Mariusz Jaremko, Karin Giller, Stefan Becker, Markus Zweckstetter

item.title: [Report] Epistasis and Allele Specificity in the Emergence of a Stable Polymorphism in Escherichia coli
item.dc:creator: Jessica Plucain
item.description: The emergence of a stable polymorphism in bacteria involved a multistep process including three specific mutations. Authors: Jessica Plucain, Thomas Hindré, Mickaël Le Gac, Olivier Tenaillon, Stéphane Cruveiller, Claudine Médigue, Nicholas Leiby, William R. Harcombe, Christopher J. Marx, Richard E. Lenski, Dominique Schneider

item.title: [Report] Humans Can Discriminate More than 1 Trillion Olfactory Stimuli
item.dc:creator: C. Bushdid
item.description: The number of different odor mixtures people can distinguish is several orders of magnitude larger than anticipated. Authors: C. Bushdid, M. O. Magnasco, L. B. Vosshall, A. Keller

item.title: [Report] Control Profiles of Complex Networks
item.dc:creator: Justin Ruths
item.description: The control profile is a network statistic that may prove useful in approaching the control of complex networks. [Also see Perspective by Onnela] Authors: Justin Ruths, Derek Ruths

item.title: [Report] Fossilized Nuclei and Chromosomes Reveal 180 Million Years of Genomic Stasis in Royal Ferns
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Bomfleur
item.description: Fern fossils provide evidence that nuclear shape, size, and chromosomal content have changed little since the Jurassic. Authors: Benjamin Bomfleur, Stephen McLoughlin, Vivi Vajda

item.title: [New Products] New Products
item.description: A weekly roundup of information on newly offered instrumentation, apparatus, and laboratory materials of potential interest to researchers.

item.title: [Podcast] Science Podcast: 21 March Show
item.description: On this week's show: human odor discrimination pegged at one trillion odors and a roundup from our daily news site.
